citeinfo.title: Peak Streamflow Codes, Anthropogenic Influences: U.S. Geological Survey GAGES-II time series data update

descript.abstract: This dataset consists of a table with information regarding anthropogenic influences from qualification codes that are part of the U.S. Geological Survey's (USGS) National Water Information System (NWIS) for sites in the Geospatial Attributes of Gages for Evaluating Streamflow II (GAGES-II) dataset. The table provides begin and end years for anthropogenic streamflow influences derived from three NWIS Peak Streamflow qualification codes; for example in what years (or if it continues) the flow record has been affected by regulation or diversion. The information here should be considered as supplemental information, and a partial list of these influences. That is, there are likely some sites here which have Regulation, Diversion, or Land Use effects not flagged in this file.
descript.purpose: These data are intended as support for research efforts using the USGS GAGES-II sites.
descript.supplinf: This dataset is in support of study sites in the GAGES-II dataset (Falcone, 2011) and based on the watershed boundaries published there. The data were retrieved and compiled by David Wolock of the U.S. Geological Survey in late December, 2015 (personal communication, D. Wolock, December, 2015), from https://nwis.waterdata.usgs.gov/usa/nwis/peak. Peak flow qualification codes are entered into NWIS by local USGS Water Science Centers and therefore may not necessarily be consistently represented across all states. Begin and end years are provided here for three qualification codes: code #5, "Discharge affected to unknown degree by Regulation or Diversion", code #6, "Discharge affected by Regulation or Diversion", and code #C, "All or part of the record affected by Urbanization, Mining, Agricultural changes, Channelization, or other" (see below for list of all codes). In addition to those six columns (begin and end years for each of those three codes), the begin and end years of all peak streamflow is given. The end year of a qualification code may be compared to the end year of all streamflow as an indication of whether or not the influence likely continues beyond the stated end year. For example, for station 12128000, code #5 and #C have end years of 2012, and the streamflow end year is also 2012. It is likely safe to assume that streamflow data beyond 2012 is also affected by the same anthropogenic influences at this site. For informational purposes, the full list of all peak flow qualification codes is provided here; but again, only data for #5, #6, and #C are given in this dataset: # 1 ... Discharge is a Maximum Daily Average # 2 ... Discharge is an Estimate # 3 ... Discharge affected by Dam Failure # 4 ... Discharge less than indicated value, which is Minimum Recordable Discharge at this site # 5 ... Discharge affected to unknown degree by Regulation or Diversion # 6 ... Discharge affected by Regulation or Diversion # 7 ... Discharge is an Historic Peak # 8 ... Discharge actually greater than indicated value # 9 ... Discharge due to Snowmelt, Hurricane, Ice-Jam or Debris Dam breakup # A ... Year of occurrence is unknown or not exact # B ... Month or Day of occurrence is unknown or not exact # C ... All or part of the record affected by Urbanization, Mining, Agricultural changes, Channelization, or other # D ... Base Discharge changed during this year # E ... Only Annual Maximum Peak available for this year The data in this dataset should be interpreted as supplemental. A lack of qualification codes for a site does not necessarily mean there are no regulation, diversion, urbanization, or other anthropogenic influences. Unlike the other datasets in this Data Release, the data here are provided for all GAGES-II sites, not just the conterminous U.S. sites. References: Falcone, J.A., 2011, GAGES-II: Geospatial Attributes of Gages for Evaluating Streamflow, U.S. Geological Survey, digital spatial data set, http://water.usgs.gov/GIS/metadata/usgswrd/XML/gagesII_Sept2011.xml. U.S. Geological Survey - National Water Information System (NWIS); Site Information, 2015, http://dx.doi.org/10.5066/F7P55KJN, Peak Streamflow Qualification Codes accessed in December 2015 at http://nwis.waterdata.usgs.gov/usa/nwis/peak.

attracc.attraccr: Values were spot checked against source data.

dataqual.logic: No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.

citeinfo.title: GAGES-II: Geospatial Attributes of Gages for Evaluating Streamflow

srcinfo.srccontr: Sites for which these data provide updated data.

citeinfo.title: U.S. Geological Survey National Water Information System (NWIS)

srcinfo.srccontr: USGS NWIS database which contains peak streamflow qualification codes

procstep.procdesc: Data were provided by David Wolock of the USGS (personal communication, D. Wolock, December, 2015), retrieved from NWIS at http://nwis.waterdata.usgs.gov/usa/nwis/peak in late December 2015.
Values of 0 indicate the site is in NWIS but no qualification given for that code. Blank values indicate the site was not retrievable from the NWIS Peak Streamflow database (a small number of sites).

enttyp.enttypl: Attribute Table for years of peak streamflow qualification codes, PeakFlow_Codes-AnthroInfl.txt.
enttyp.enttypd: Data consist of a comma-separated text file..
